entry.title: Combined summary - [PATCH] First draft of option_simplfied_commitment
entry.summary: The Lightning Network developers have been discussing the implementation of anchor outputs, which would allow for more efficient opening and closing of Lightning channels. Anchor outputs would enable each party to have their own Bitcoin transaction that locks funds in a multi-sig address. However, several issues need to be addressed before implementing anchor outputs, such as the need for both parties to pay for their own anchors, the dust limit negotiated in the open_channel or accept_channel message, and key rotation to prevent brute-forcing hacks by watchtowers.In addition to anchor outputs, the developers are also considering a new commitment format for Lightning Network channels. The initial proposal was to use a single "to_self_delay" value, but there were concerns raised about the possibility of insufficient fees resulting in stuck channels. To address this, the team is looking at adding a CSV time lock to every non-anchor output on the commitment transaction to ensure minimal fees and prevent gaming situations. The conversation also highlights ongoing efforts to improve the Lightning Network's scalability and security. One concern raised was the possibility of channels getting stuck due to unbalanced transactions, which could be mitigated by reusing `dust_limit_satoshis` or adding a new `anchor_msat` field in the opening messages. The CheckLockTimeVerify (CLTV) feature was discussed, with concerns raised about its sufficiency in addressing the issue of timelocking in the lightning network. A simpler alternative was suggested by appending `1 OP_CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY OP_DROP` to the start of each script without any difference in script length.Furthermore, there were discussions on negotiation of transaction fees between nodes and channel management rules. Each commitment transaction uses a unique set of keys generated from a series of per-commitment secrets that are generated from a single seed to improve network performance. The HTLC-success and HTLC-timeout transactions use `local_delayedpubkey` and `revocationpubkey`. The sending node is required to set the initial `fee_satoshis` according to its estimate of the cost of inclusion in a block and MUST set signature to the Bitcoin signature of the close.The Lightning Network development team is working on implementing a policy hack that requires a CSV delay of 1 block on HTLC transaction outputs. This aims to ensure that the carve-out exception of "last tx in a package, which has only one unconfirmed ancestor" is always available for the "honest party" when broadcasting a commitment transaction. If `option_simplified_commitment` applies to the commitment transaction, then `feerate_per_kw` is 253. There are also discussions on whether to rotate keys or not, with three options presented. While there is a suggestion to create anchor outputs that are economical to spend and adaptable to changes in fee rates, it is noted that the protocol's complexity may pose a problem. Overall, the developers are continuing to work on improving the Lightning Network and ensuring its scalability and security.
